summary: Japanese peasants Matashichi (Kamatari Fujiwara) and Tahei (Minoru Chiaki) try and fail to make a profit from a tribal war. They find a man and woman whom they believe are simple tribe members hiding in a fortress. Although the peasants don't know that Rokurota (Toshirô Mifune) is a general and Yuki (Misa Uehara) is a princess, the peasants agree to accompany the pair to safety in return for gold. Along the way, the general must prove his expertise in battle while also hiding his identity.

reviews.content: enjoyed watching the George Lucas interview first to see what inspirations he took from this movie for Star Wars. Interesting that such a strong female character has been so overlooked from a movie in the 50's.

George Lucas was inspired by this movie's story, characters, and sequences and it really does show in many scenes how the material overlapped into one of the best made trilogies of all time. That was one of my main reasons for giving this movie a try and I actually really liked it! The acting was convincing, the action and duels/fights were very well directed for the time, and the story was original and captivating throughout! Akira Kurosawa was quite the film artist and inspired generations with his work, and all of the main cast members did real justice with the roles they were given. Plus, the scenery and wide shots in many scenes were gorgeous as well!

Another Kurosawa masterpiece, The Hidden Fortress is a fun and really well done film that is just a fun and engaging watch! Great character portrayals and a stunning screenplay filled with adventure and stunning battles. Mifune gives a reserved and masterful performance that is typical of the legendary actor. An amazing film that holds up amazingly well and is a pleasure to watch!
Maybe for 1958 it was a decent film, but now it is very slow paced. Had some funny moments, but mostly irritating and boring.

Controversial opinion but I think this is Kurosawa's best samurai film. Maybe his only truly entertaining film with good characters, a lot of action and a fun, easily understood plot. I really enjoyed watching and certainly rate it higher than it's Star Wars follow ups.

A stylish and flat-out enjoyable samurai movie, The Hidden Fortress is perhaps best known by the American public for its influence on Star Wars, but is a brilliant and accessible movie in its own right.

I just couldn't get into this one.  The story is subpar, the humor falls flat, and Misa Uehara is not a very good actress.  Director Kurosawa does manage to present some impressive set pieces here and there though.

This classic Akira Kurosawa film came 4 years after the Seven Samurai.  The story of a rebel princess trying to covertly get back to her kingdom with the aid of a loyal Samurai and two bumbling peasants is engaging, funny, and multilayered.  I know George Lucas says it impacted Star Wars.  While it is clear to me that Dune was his major story influence that there are elements of this film in Star Wars.  The Enemy warriors' helmets are the foundation for Darth Vader's. In 1958 the role of Princess Yuki as a defiant, bold, tough, but feminine character is clearly a forerunner to Princess Leia.  After reading about Lucas it seems clear to me that R2D2 and C3PO are modeled after Hidden Fortress's two main characters, the bumbling, often at odds, peasants.  A great film.
Wonderful combination of comedy in a dark time. Both stories are shown so well.
Fun little romp with some real lovable characters.
Great story but the two peasants should have been played straight or left out completely.
Yes, yes, I've seen Star Wars. Now see the original.

The Hidden Fortress is another amazing film made by Akira Kurosawa. I love the performances of Toshiro Mifune and Misa Uehara, the humor, the story, and battle sequences. Even though this film may be not remembered as much as other Kurosawa's films, The Hidden Fortress helped bring us Star Wars. Overall, this movie help paved the way for the creation of both R2-D2 and C3PO.

Kurosawa's love for exploring the flaws of characters is immediately evident in Hidden Fortress, but many of the complex themes that he explored in similar films are noticeably absent. This is a much more simplistic and easily digestible entry in the master's catalog, but the sharply defined characters and the interesting perspective of the inherently unlikable pair of 'protagonists' make this an interesting film regardless. (4/5)

The movie that turned my opinion of Kurosawa around. He said in an interview that with this movie he set out to create a piece of pure entertainment, and good God that's exactly what he did. Bonus points if you're able to catch all the stuff that Star Wars pulled from it. Definitely watch if you like classic films.
With a grasp full of entertainment, it will serve and please fans of the genre and director as well as those looking for the inspiration for Star Wars.

Probably the most accessible of Kurosawa's movies. The story is creative and the pacing is not as challenging as some of his other movies. 

This movie gets five stars mostly because its so good that you can't even describe why.

A true epic. It's a comedy, a drama, a war film, a samurai film. Certain scenes are absolutely stunning. The Fire Festival, the show down between two warriors, and the final shots are just incredible. A must see for film lovers.

An entertaining and influential adventure!

Akira Kurosawa's Japanese adventure comedy The Hidden Fortress (1958) is an imaginative journey of transporting gold and a princess. It's not a flawless masterpiece of filmmaking like some of Kurosawa's other epics. I much prefer Rashomon, Ikiru, and Seven Samurai, but The Hidden Fortress is sure to delight fans of Kurosawa all the same for its good humor and neat adventure aspects alone. Kurosawa's writing is centered around laughter and fun instead of high moral concepts, but he does cover The Hidden Fortress' main theme of loyalty well.

Kurosawa's story appears to have been highly influential of George Lucas for Star Wars' concepts for A New Hope as well as Sergio Leone's The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly from what I watched. You can see the side wipes made popular in A New Hope here in The Hidden Fortress first. The duel between old samurai comrades is not unlike Ben Kenobi and Darth Vader's chance encounter. The similarities go on and on really. The search for gold and the fool's greed leading to betrayal feels like Tuco endlessly betraying The Man with No Name in The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly. The two fools come across as lecherous versions of C-3PO and R2-D2 questing for gold with Star Wars from their perspective. In short, The Hidden Fortress is a fun adventure on its own merits, but its ideas are timeless archetypes for future film plotlines.

Kurosawa's direction is entertaining with farcical bits splitting up the epic adventure with some silly comedy. Not all the jokes land and hit hard, but you'll likely enjoy The Hidden Forest. It does get rather long and slow in the middle, but there is plenty of payoff with exciting chases and humorous diversions. Masaru Sato's score is uplifting and exciting with boisterous music!

Toshiro Mifune is the main draw as the cool samurai general in hiding Rokurota Makabe trying his best to outsmart two idiots and save his princess' life. Misa Uehara is fiery and intense in a playful role as Princess Yuki. I must mention Minoru Chiaki as Tahei and Kamatari Fujiwara as Matashichi. They are hilarious and a constant source of laughter in The Hidden Fortress. You feel bad as these two unlikely heroes desperately try to survive warfare, conquer their foes, and claim hidden gold as their own. They are made more ridiculous next to the ultra serious Mifune for extra laughs.

The Hidden Fortress is not a flawless adventure, but it is a genuinely funny one.

The Hidden Fortress is a somewhat weaker Akira Kurosawa fare which benefits from strong audio-visuals, excellent characterization, different, amusing protagonists and a great adventurous approach, but it is obviously very lacking thematically speaking and its runtime is needlessly protracted.
Not Kurosawa's best work.  Unlike his other great films, The Hidden Fortress struggles with pacing and a sloppy narrative.

This is a black and white film and I was in absolute stitches! The bumbling bandits were so funny and the story was so compelling. I loved it! And I don't love Star Wars. If anything, George Lucas should have copied more.

The Hidden Fortress has a listless, droll structure to it that is likely due to its reliance on the comedy genre, but that doesn't stop it from being seriously entertaining, and very funny, even with some serious classism going on.
This film was solid.

As much as I appreciate Kurosawa's sense of entertainment and ever-relevant humanist through lines, The Hidden Fortress felt somewhat flat and overlong. Even though I love Mifune in this, and can appreciate the immeasurable influence in action movies to come, I prefer Kurosawa when he's more clinical and introspective.

Weak, especially by Kurosawa's high standards.

In the middle of a war, two peasants trying to escape the fighting stumble across a man who persuades them to help him move his gold to a safer area.  He turns out to be Rokurota Makabea, a famous general in the army of Akizuki, the invaded country.  The two peasants scheme to enrich themselves at the General's expense, but he foils their every attempt.  However, he is also transporting someone more precious than gold - Princess Yuki, the heir to the Akizuki throne.  There is a bounty on her head and the journey will be a perilous one.

Not Akira Kurosawa's best work - far from it.  Pretty slow-moving and dull, with little profundity or grittiness.  Essentially one long, linear road movie.

Starts off slowly and never seems to find even second gear.  Every scene gets drawn out to the max.  No real focus either, just a long winding walk of a movie.

Making things worse is the presence of the two peasants.  Incredibly irritating and silly characters, they are largely responsible for the movie feeling so lacking in substance.  Whether through bad writing, direction, casting or performance - I suspect a combination of the four - they have a profoundly negative impact on the movie.

The opening scenes of The Hidden Fortress are a little scattered. It establishes the peasants played by Minoru Chiaki and Kamatari Fujiwara, but they just seem to be bouncing around from one place to another. I really enjoy these characters, because they have a humorous report with one another. Admittedly they are a bit infuriating because they constantly make the wrong decisions, but they had enough personality that I found it funny instead of frustrating. They are the catalyst that gets the story going, but I still wonder if the movie really needed to start and end with them. Either way, after a little bit of rambling, the story settles down and hits its stride once that first piece of gold is found.

This is where Toshiro Mifune joins the movie and suddenly elevates it to another level. His interactions with the peasants is priceless because he is always two steps ahead of them. He also adds a lot of charm and gravitas to any character he portrays. Misa Uehara is superb as the strong princess who pretends to be mute for a large portion of the movie. Her clear dominance over Mifunes character is exciting to watch because it makes her the most important character in the film despite the fact that she barely speaks. There are a few other vital roles in the movie but this quartet are the ones that work together the longest and I love the arc of their story.

There were some moments where I longed for some of the more dramatic samurai fights that Ive seen in a couple of other Kurosawa films. The most significant fight in the film is done with spears instead of swords which seems a bit clunky, even if the scene still has a lot of intense dramatic moments. The plot carried The Hidden Fortress despite some minor tweaks I would have enjoyed seeing. I found this to be a well-made film that I would gladly revisit. You can certainly see a few places where George Lucas drew inspiration from The Hidden Fortress in the story and with some of the character creation. But I was glad to see plenty of differences so you couldnt accuse Star Wars of being a remake, at most it is an homage to this classic.
Excellent adventure movie.  The comedy is really refreshing for one of these feudal movies.  Fun characters in an entertaining story.

Seeing that actor get his head trampled by the horse was like woah. It's very obvious to see all the inspiration this movie had on the Star War movies. Even the soundtrack sounds similar with whistles and sort of orchestral-like at times. The transitions between scenes are a dead give away also. As always, Kurosawa's use of extras is impressive and amazing.

I love how the story just chugs along very easily as if a genius wrote the story out. Even though the movie is in black and white, I can definitely tell that the locations used are beautiful. It makes me want to visit that part of Japan or wherever it was filmed. That being said, the way the movie was filmed is wonderful as well. Very elegantly done.

Matacischi and Tahei bring the comedy and humor to the movie resembling the likes of R2D2 and C3PO. Kurosawa's famous use of fog makes itself present again.

Overall, splendiferous movie with great characters and plot.
Akira Kurosawa is among the absolute greats of directing. The Hidden Fortress is a tense, engaging, and funny story full of charismatic and spunky characters.
Plenty of comic relief in this one.

No doubt a significant movie historically, as it is the predecessor to many modern action adventure movies, but far from Kurosawa's best. I feel like in an attempt to make a much lighter hearted movie, too much mystery and spontaneity was removed to make the story more linear and easier for a general audience to appreciate. 

Not to say that the story is bad, but when compared to other Kurosawa films, the best parts of Hidden Fortress pale in comparison. The use of peasants as an introduction to a story with a much larger scope is cool, but done better in Seven Samurai. The same goes for it's period detail. 

At over two hours it is treading into the run time of some of his epics, which does not feel justified by the much smaller character driven story.

I probably sound like I didn't like the movie, but it's really not a bad movie by any means. This is Kurosawa at a lower point and it still years ahead of the competition.

5 stars for cinematography. Story was lighter than the other Kurosawa films I have seen, both in substance and tone.

It is often mentioned how influential this film was in setting the building blocks for Lucas and Spielberg's blockbusters. As for setting a template for Star Wars, it was the weakest element of Hidden Fortress that carried over to the space fantasy. The two peasants are the banchmark for annoying comic relief characters like c-3P0 and R2D2, but I was thinking they were also much like Jar Jar Binks, sans Jamaican accent.

There are several scenes in this film that, on their own, could define an entire movie. Criterion's restoration leaves nothing to be desired.

This alluring epic from Akira Kurosawa is a grandiose adventure characterised by gorgeous sets and lofty explorations of greed and loyalty.
Hidden Fortress is perhaps one of the great auteur's more understated masterpieces, but viewers ought to remember that without it, we wouldn't have Star Wars, and we'd likely have missed out on many a Sergio Leone western along the way. Elegant in its simplicity, the film is peppered with good humour and unforgettable exchanges - more than a handful of which have have left indelible marks on modern cinema as we know it.
The film is undoubtedly overlong, with a tendency to sway softly between its moments of greatness, but this only renders each all the more rewarding, reflective and resonant. So sit back, and let poetry unfold before your very eyes.

Akiro Kurosawa's masterpiece and the template adopted by George Lucas for Star Wars.  As a matter of fact C3PO and R2D2 are the two protagonists here.  Even Princess Leia is directly influenced by the princess in this film.  I highly recommend this movie to those who do not have a problem watching foreign films.

a good as any classic Kurosawa's masterpieces go. Hidden Fortress follows a ambitious narration which the story is unfolded by two seemingly irreverent and unlikable characters. As the story progresses, we get to see the bigger picture of the film which is about a revolution of an ethical kingdom. The film eventually inspires Lucas to make the first Star War, and Hidden Fortress sure is a more stylish approach of such theme.
Packed with action and wildly diverse characters, Akira Kurosawa's runaway epic is a fun (if occasionally overacted) winner!

It's entertaining from start to finish but what pushes the film into the level of greatness is that the film's two central characters are greedy cowards who Kurosawa somehow manages to get the audience to completely empathize with.

Definitely one of the funniest of Kurosawa with lighthearted dynamic between Tahei, Matashichi, and Rokurouta. Boasting intense horse mounted duels and magnificent, textural rocky landscapes, The Hidden Fortress is a definitively essential watch for Kurosawa fans and historical film enthusiasts alike.

This is a great film from Akira Kurosawa and one of the primary influences on George Lucas for "Star Wars".  I first saw it a long time ago and didn't remember it well, so watching the new 2k digital restoration was an amazing experience.  This was Kurosawa's first widescreen film and he makes the most of it.  The story is highly entertaining and the cinematography outstanding, the movie is definitely the work of a Master on his game.  I also loved all the performances including the great Toshiro Mifune.  This is a MUST watch for all movie lovers!

defenetly not the best work of Kurosawa but one of his most fun. this movie has one of the best duel scenes i have seen .  interesting fun adeventure movie with unique storytelling  that later was used by George Lucas in Star Wars . 
if you want to get into Kurosawa movies this is a very good movie to start .
Star Wars' fun origin.
My second favorite Kurosawa movie. You can easily see the influence George Lucas derived from this.

The film that inspired Star Wars. You can see a lot of elements that George Lucas used in this Kurosawa epic. While not Kurosawa's greatest, it is still an entertaining and funny adventure story with some great storytelling. 

Grade: B+
Blah blah blah Star Wars was based on this movie but don't let that put you off. This is actually pure class.

Out of all the films from Akira Kurosawa that i have seen, The Hidden Fortress might acturlly be my favorite. Kurosawa proves once again that he was one of the best storytellers in cinema. Fun characters, great story and great performances, not to mention the beautiful cinematography and locations. It may not be as deep as his other films like Seven Samurai and Rashomon, but it is without a doubt one of his most entertaining. 

This film was acturlly one of George Lucas' biggest inspirations for Star Wars and you will definitely notice the similarities between the two films while watching it, in terms of it's storystructure. But for me, that might have explained why i find this film so fun and entertaining, since i love these kinds of stories. 

But yeah, great film and in my opnion one of Kurosawa's absolute best.
An enjoyable, thoughtful, and at times epic Japanese adventure film.

Kurosawa's sort of road movie/comedy/action adventure thing comes somewhere in the middle of his best run of films. Good as it is, it has a risk of being caught in the shadow of career highlights like High and Low or Seven Samurai.

But, putting aside the fact that it's a fairly lightweight film, there's a lot to enjoy here Kamatari Fujiwara and Minoru Chiaki are great as the bickering peasants who get caught up in a much bigger story. Mifune doesn't do anything he hasn't done before in other Kurowsawa films: he acts noble and glowers a lot. Except this time in slightly incongruous short-shorts. 

It's funny, breezy, has some great action and typically astonishing composition: some of the shots near the start of the film in the wrecked city are mind boggling.

After the release and success of Throne of Blood (1957), Japanese writer/director Akira Kurosawa now had a proud and successful reputation in Japan and audiences around the world. For his next film, Kurosawa decided to lighten the tone a bit, noting that Throne of Blood has been a dark film, claiming "I want to make a 100% entertainment film, full of thrills and fun." He certainly delivers here. It begins with two poor peasants, Tahei (Minoru Chiaki) and Matashichi (Kamatari Fujiwara), who had intended to fight with the Yamana clan against the Akizuki clan, but arrived at the battle too late. They bicker and argue before splitting up, but it's not long before they're both captured by the Yamana clan, mistaken for Akizuki. But, Tahei and Mataschichi both manage to escape, and they find a stash of Akizuki gold down by a river, but they're approached by Akizuki General Makabe Rokur?ta (Toshiro Mifune), who tells them he's escorting Princess Yuki Akizuki (Misa Uehara), and they're trying to hide the gold from the Yamana clan, they join in on this mission. It's an intriguing and compelling adventure film, Kurosawa's first film in widescreen, and it's got a good sense of humour about it, as well as some good action. The characters of Tahei and Matashichi were influenses for R2D2 and C3PO in Star Wars (1977), and the mission inspired The Good, the Bad and the Ugly (1966).
Kurosawa does a great job with blending tension, action, and comedy in this remarkable film.  Toshiro Mifune is as great as ever.

Kurosawa's "hidden fortress" is but a briefly used setting compared to his signature storytelling that focuses on what holds us back from happiness and how people change -or don't- when it comes their way.
two poor peasants are hired to escort a princess through enemy territory. A touch too long, fight scenes lacked a little in quality and quantity this time around

Fabulous movie. A great mix of action , drama and comedy hence a complete entertainment package. Kurosawa does a great job and well edited too, it's still quite a long movie. But complete entertainment.

*THE OFFICIAL BETTER THAN JUNO SEAL*

Ahhh...it's been a while since I've given a film a 9/10.  And what better way too do it than with Akira Kurosawa's The Hidden Fortress, an important piece in cinema history for many reasons.  You may be wondering why this may be....Well, Star Wars would not exist if it weren't for this film.  Yes, you fanboy nerds heard me right.  Your precious Star Wars wouldn't even exist if it weren't for this film.  However, the Hidden Fortress is more than just an inspiring film...It's one of the best.  Though it may boast more style than substance, there is a lot to love about this Japanese epic.

The Forbidden Fortress is about two dimwitted lowlifes, who don't care much for this world.  They are forced to work for a rival clan, doing hard labor.  They plot to escape, and they almost do.  But they get caught.  They are turned into slaves, working with the slaves.  However, they escape after an uprising and end up at a river full of gold.  There they meet two people: a man and chick, who turn out to be the general and princess of a fallen clan.  They are tasked with a simple, yet dangerous mission: Lead the two people out of the territory and into safety.  If you cannot see the hint of Star Wars within that premise, you obviously didn't watch Star Wars cause that's nearly identical.....except this film is set on Earth.

One of the best things I noted from this film was Kurosawa's directing.  The overall style of the film makes it seem much superior to Star Wars.  Also, the film is deeply comical.  Never would I have thought I wouldn't laugh with a film made 6 decades ago, but this film works.  It's witty, snappy dialogue is more than anything Lucas could do.  Also, the acting seemed to be great, though it is hard to understand due to language barriers.  However, it doesn't matter, seeing that I don't mind reading a little.  I think it's witty script and likable characters push this film well beyond the Star Wars films (sorry Han Solo).  Even if you don't like talky films, this film has plenty of action to keep you entertained for the entire 2hr 10min runtime, which flies by really quickly.  

Now, I get sick and tired of people who won't watch a film because it's black and white, so I decided to make an open letter to them.  Dear whoever you are, please quit being so ignorant.  Just cause a film may not have the best technical merits (cause it's old) doesn't mean it doesn't have any merits.  The Hidden Fortress is a wonderfully written film and if you won't watch it cause it's "old", you are really missing out on great films.  I'm not saying you're an idiot, but just be a little more open in films.  I'm getting sick of all those Paranormal Activity films, but I'll still watch them if I can....Maybe.  I'm just saying: give it a try.  If it's not your thing, it's not your thing.  Just experiment.

Overall, The Hidden Fortress is the first fully fledged 9/10 review I've given in the past 3 months.  It's always curious to see the obvious similarities between this and Star Wars, so I have made a game: Count how many things Star Wars used from this film.  Trust me, it's a lot.  Featuring witty dialogue, great battle scenes, and some nice open shots of an entire set piece, Kurosawa proves as to why he's a great director.  He seamlessly shifts from humor to action to humor again and again.  If you decide you don't want to watch it cause it's black and white, you're missing one of the best films ever that "inspired" one of the biggest franchises of all time.  Not only is this a must see for Kurosawa fans (though I'm sure most have already seen it), it's a must see for Star Wars fans.  Great time.  Thank you, Criterion for remastering the film.
This story about a princess trying to escape through enemy territory was George Lucas's primary influence for "Star Wars." Wonderful movie, highly recommended.

I was intrigued to see The Hidden Fortress, not only because it was an Akira Kurosawa film, but George Lucas apparently cited the film as a major inspiration for the legendary Star Wars franchise (Hell, Lucas was such a fan of Kurosawa that he served as an executive producer for Kagemusha when Kurosawa and Toho had difficulty financing the film). Sure enough, upon watching The Hidden Fortress, it certainly lived up to its lofty reputation as one of the greatest adventure films of all time and yet another triumph for the legendary director.

Two bumbling peasants: Matashichi and Tahei end up getting taken on the ride of their lives in the wake of the country's clan warfare. After being forced to dig ditches to bury bodies and search for a missing bounty of 200 pieces of gold in the ruins of the Akizuki Clan's castle, the two end up discovering a piece of the clan's gold hidden in the mountains while traveling through.

Knowing that the Yamana Clan is searching for these pieces of gold, the peasants begin desperately searching the area for more gold, when they run into a man named Rokurota who takes the two men and forces them to work for him with promises of gold. 

It turns out Rokurota is actually a guard for the missing princess of the Akizuki Clan named Yuki and plans to get her to another clan territory for safe-keeping to start the clan over. When the peasants, despite being generally stupid, present a good plan for getting past the Yamana Clan territory, Rokurota decides to take Princess Yuki along with this plan, making her pretend to be a mute to protect her, while also recruiting the bumbling and greedy peasants to help smuggle the gold to their destination that is hidden in pieces of wood. During their journey, they also purchase and rescue a servant girl, and now the five unlikely allies must cross the dangerous territories, with the peasants unknowingly escorting the princess to safety.

The story is definitely much more light-hearted than many of Kurosawa's other works, but he proves that is more than capable of light-hearted and delivers one hell of a ride as far as adventure films go. The characters each have their own distinct personalities as any good adventure film should and the characters are very well rounded and interesting. It's a story filled with action, adventure, humor, suspense, excitement, and so much more. As far as storytelling goes, any fan of adventure films should find a lot to love in here.

Once again, especially with a cast that includes Toshiro Mifune, the acting is quite good. While this is one of his more light-hearted roles, Mifune seemed to have no trouble adapting to what kind of character a script would call for. Every cast member was great, and all the main characters became endearing and entertaining to follow on their bizarre journey.

The Hidden Fortress is certainly among the greatest adventure films of all time. If you enjoyed the Star Wars franchise, you should check this film out because of how much the much more famous franchise owes to this film. This film has anything any fan of adventure films, Japanese films, Kurosawa films, or lovers of great films could pretty much ever want. It's a superb film that is action-packed, exciting, fun, hilarious, and more. See it if you ever get a chance to watch it.
Just a fun samurai adventure movie. Not deep or emotional like his other movies, but still solid and entertaining. Also, spears.
another actioner from acclaimed japanese director kurosawa
At times it drags on, but for the most part Hidden Fortress is an entertaining comic adventure. This is a good Kurosawa, but most certainly not one of his greats.
Hapless heroes can be trusted for their greed. Slow pace goes with the genre.  Mufune shines as babysitter to his well cast co-stars.

The Hidden Fortress may be best known for being the primary inspiration for Star Wars, but what people tend to forget is that this is actually the superior film. Its unusual blend of humor and action was quite rare for the 1950s, especially in Japan, where the film was dismissed by many film critics for having too much of a "Western feel" to it. Still, it's my favorite Japanese film, and deserves its place as a notable classic of foreign cinema.

The Hidden Fortress follows two bumbling peasants who, after going off to war, are forced to return to their village with their tails between their legs. Fortunately, on their way back they come across an old general, who enlists them to help transport an enormous cache of gold and a princess from enemy territory into her own ravaged kingdom. And yes, they're more than a little reminiscent of R2-D2 and C-3PO. The opening scene, where they're walking through a desert wasteland while bickering, is more than enough to give Star Wars fans goosebumps.

Meanwhile, the general is clearly Obi-Wan Kenobi (and his name even sounds eerily reminiscent of that infamous name), and there is, of course, an epic scene in which he duels with the baddie. But plot points aren't the only thing that Star Wars took from Kurosawa, and it took plenty of 'em... no, the style is also clearly the precursor to Star Wars. The long and dramatic landscape shots, the timing of the dialogue, the scene transitions-- they're all very Lucas-esque. If only Lucas had been able to capture the dialogue and character development as well as the style, Star Wars could have been even better.

The real feat of this movie is that, even though it was subtitled, I still laughed out loud at some of the character's dialogue. Usually, subtitled films make it hard for a viewer to judge the acting, as the line delivery is in another language, and therefore you don't know how well the acting is. They could be droning on in a monotone, screwing up their lines, or giving delivery reminiscent of The Room for all we know. However, The Hidden Fortress didn't make me feel that way once. Throughout the film, I was completely engrossed with the characters, which is an unusual thing for a subtitled film to do. Altogether an incredible cinematic feat.

The story, meanwhile, is a total classic. In the interview with George Lucas, he mentions an old adage saying that there are only 32 stories that can be told. He said he didn't subscribe to that belief, neither do I, and I doubt Kurosawa did either. He told a truly remarkable story with this movie, the likes of which had never been seen before by Japanese or western audiences. That's probably why his films are so repeatedly adapted, from the obvious Star Wars to A Fistful of Dollars and The Magnificent Seven. Filmmakers nowadays would do well to learn from his example, but unfortunately, it looks as if character development and sharp dialogue have been all but lost to time.

Final Score for The Hidden Fortress: 9/10 stars. Really, the only reason I'm not giving it a 10 is because I am very stingy with my 10/10s, and don't like to use them much. I wouldn't be surprised if, upon another look, I saw fit to give this the rare Diego Tutweiller 10/10 Approval Rating... but until then, I'll be digging into my brain searching for a flaw in this spectacular film.
Story telling, music is ahead of its time.  A pleasure to watch a remastered black and white film in such performance quality.

By doing what "The Greatest Film-Director" did with the pure solemn poetry of Rashomon, he did with a Samurai-epic comedy, and also inspired the "Greatest Sci-Fi franchise of all time"- Star Wars-  How else can I acclaim Kurosawa of shaping what today we know as Modern Film-making, even simple perfect story-telling with that spark of Japanese epicness? The Hidden Fortress is a great action comedy movie that puts all others to shame. Itâ(TM)s scandalous that todayâ(TM)s audiences have to tolerate clichÃ (C)d Lethal Weapon-type dialogue and excessive explosions; this film shows that a director can do both well, along with the usual Akira Kurosawa theme of how does one act morally in an immoral world.

Is the ultimate goal profit or the greater good? Each character tries to discover this during the film.  Is the ultimate goal DVD sales, audience enjoyment, or greater a work that stands out as one of the greatest of all time?  Kurosawa accomplishes all three.

Action and comedy are perfectly balanced. When this film was made, Kurosawa had already proven his ability to conceive great action sequences, build suspense over the course of a film, create emotional close shots between characters, and manipulate light and shadow expertly. In this work, he displays that he can write and direct humourous comedy scenes. He also permits the audience to infer certain details, rather than dumbing down the plot to the lowest common denominator.

The story is told from the point of view of a hapless duo (Tahei and Matashichi) engender audience sympathy despite their crooked nature because of their hilarious exchanges. The protagonists continually argue with each other yet each is enitrely dependent on the other. Those scoundrels walk the line between complete cowardice, utter idiocy, and giddy greed. They move from one misadventure to another following a selfish quest to profit by any means necessary during an ongoing war.

I believe that Kurosawa pioneered the idea of screen wipes as a transition from one scene to another. Unlike George Lucas, he makes the wipe part of the scene, allowing the briefest snapshots (such as when the two jackanapes are pursued for stealing rice) to make the film more dynamic. The score suits the action beautifully. The scene when a mob of destitute prisoners of war escape and overwhelm the organized Samurai army is a great example of Kurosawaâ(TM)s grand vision, as is the sword fight on horseback.

Tahei and Matashichi follow a general (ToshirÃ´ Mifune) and a princess through enemy lines, although they are unaware of their stature at the time. The beggars initially join the gang and face danger for the promise of gold but at the end receive self-satisfaction because they contributed to a good cause, despite the lack of reward.

This film should be screen at the Bloor Cinema; I think the audience would feel comfortable laughing at the many light-hearted moments. Although I complimented Mifune during a previous post for his great range, he seems to find a way to work the same laugh into every film. The Hidden Fortress is highly recommended (and totally ridiculous).

It may seem a little over the top or dated these days, but then you realise that the almost theatrical style helped enormously to establish the characters' personalities. A film you have to sit down and watch, and not something easily digestible like many mainstream fare these days.

Being a very engaging film, The Hidden Fortress is an action-packed adventure that also combines elements of a joyful comedy. Set in the times of feudal Japan, against the devastating Civil War, it's Kurosawa's auteur vision of a journey that binds two easygoing and cunning misfits, and a ruthless general in search of gold, and on a quest to save a gorgeous princess. It beautifully presents Japanese culture from within, making it an interesting piece for anyone, who wants to get a glimpse at the peculiarity and loveliness of the country of cherry blossoms. What's more, it adds up to the overall excitement with great sword-fighting sequences. A masterpiece.

Star Wars is said to be a remake of The Hidden Fortress, but while it was certainly an influence I'd say "remake" is an overstatement. The plot focuses on two bumbling peasants (Minoru Chiaki and Kamatari Fujiwara) falling into the service of a gruff general (Toshiro Mifune) as they carry a cache of gold and help an exiled princess (Misa Uehara). This movie differs from Akira Kurosawa's other samurai stories by having the narrative focus on the two idiots who'd probably be the minor comic relief of most other films. Those looking for parallels to Star Wars may be disappointed, but most others will be impressed by the action, characterization, and ever-stunning direction.

Akira Kurosawa's one of finest works, with his longtime collaborator Toshiro Mifune. 

Film begins with two funnily cowards Tahei (Minoru Chiaki) and Matashichi (Kamatari Fujiwara) running from the battle in feudal Japan in 16th century. They encounter General Rokurota Makabe (Toshiro Mifune), who is guarding Princess Yuki Akizuki (Misa Uehara), and her gold in a secret land. They want to flee the area. 

Toshiro Mifune, plays the role of General in style and vigor, he is robust while dealing with Tahei and Matashichi throughout the movie; showing his superiority both through physique and expressions. He subjugates to Princess Yuki's tomboy attitude. Tahei and Matashichi characters in this film are fun to watch, as director George Lucas himself mentioned that creation of characters C3PO and R2D2, were inspiration from these two characters of Hidden Fortress.  You just love to watch them irritate Toshiro Mifune. They put him to trouble with their idiotic actions every now and then, they are full of greed to get hold of gold of Princess Yuki.

Kazuo Yamasaki applies exceptional cinematography, to first ever wide-screen film by Akira Kurosawa. Roof-top photography of locations is excellent and stunning to look at. Let me also mention superb music-score by Masaru Sato, especially during search for gold by Tahei and Mtashichi, while Toshiro misleads them!

Equally good is Toshirô Mifune who plays the general; a more serious character but still able to provide a few laughs as well as some action. Misa Uehara is likable as the tomboyish Princess Yuki; a good strong female character. The story flows nicely and doesn't seem overly long despite being well over two hours long. If you are a fan of Kurosawa's other works or Japanese cinema in general this is a must see.its nature distorted by its status as the official "inspiration" for "Star Wars", "the Hidden Fortress" is a unique delight in the Kurosawa canon, balancing wry humor and deep empathy on the line between realism and fairy tale. The film opens and closes with the two bickering farmer/soldiers who inspired R2-D2 and C3P0, but they're nothing like their "Star Wars" descendants -- their swings from slapstick to base treachery make them so weird and un-Hollywood that Lucas' robots seem neutered by comparison. Mandatory viewing, for many reasons.

The film that inspired Star Wars is it's superior in every way. Kurosawa's jidai-geki film does not take place in galaxies far far away, but in the mountains along feudal territory borders. The character don't travel in technologically advanced (and realistically impossible) pods or spaceships, but on horses and often by foot. The lead actors in Star Wars like Harrison Ford are rubbish and wooden compared to the commanding and mature performance given by Toshiro Mifune. Nothing in any Hollywood action film is as exhilarating as seeing him hunt down two enemy soldiers on horseback with both his hands on the handle of his sword (not some oversized glow stick). The fierce voice that Misa Uehara brings with her to the role of the princess puts Carrie Fisher's unspectacular performance to shame. Furthermore, the dull interaction between C3PO and R2D2 pales in comparison to the hilarious comedy of Minoru Chiaki and Kamatari Fujiwara. The two peasants are not helping the princess because of loyalty or some power of the force, in fact they don't even know she's the princess! They are just doing it to get their share of 200 gold pieces which are being smuggled along with the princess. So their motivation is simply greed, which is easier to relate to and makes much more sense psychologically. The greed of the two bumbling peasants allows for a much more complex relationship to develop between them, the princess, and the general (Toshiro Mifune). They are not simply sidekicks or henchmen, they have their own desires and intentions which further create tension and conflict. Their greed is also a commentary on the selfishness of people in society. In terms of direction, of course Kurosawa's film flows much more smoothly, more naturally, and more coherently than Star Wars, which was very awkward at times as it went from one scene to another; this is because Kurosawa's use of slide wipe are more fluent in their execution and seem like transitions, while Lucas' forced use of those same slide wipes seem like skipping. Ultimately, Hidden Fortress is an thrilling adventure with 4 memorable characters who have incredible experiences which are such a joy to watch. Funny it was easier to relate to a film set 500 years in the past than a film set 500 (or more) years in the future. Well, to give to some props to George Lucas atleast he did admit this film's influence on Star Wars, at least he changed the name of the film, and he also helped finance Kurosawa's late epic Kagemusha; don't be misled though the real respect should be paid to Kurosawa, the Emperor of filmmaking.

7/7: Kurosawa continues his winning streak with me with another splendid film. "The Hidden Fortress'" story concerns two men (and best friends for that matter) who are displaced during a kingdom civil war (wars between various kingdoms within Japan) and are imprisoned. They manage to escape, however, when the other prisoners revolt against the guards. After they go on a hunt for a wanted princess, in which they would receive a substantial gold reward if they capture her. At the same time, they also go on a hunt for gold in the mountains. Soon though, another man (Tishiro Mifune) persuades them to take him on as their boss and then they go on a hunt for gold. They soon discover he is associated with the wanted princess and the film goes onto interesting direction from there on. Highly entertaining work from the Japanese master. Beautifully filmed, emphasizing both the scenery (mountains and landscape), towns, and fighting throughout the film. The Fire Festival scene is astonishingly impressive. The acting is also fine and so is the humorous translated dialogue. Another great film from the repertoire of Akira Kurosawa.

If Japanese cinema icon Akira Kurosawa ever made a comedy of sorts, this is it.  The Hidden Fortress follows two bumbling, stumbling, bickering peasants named Matashichi and Tahei -- the odd couple of samurai flicks -- on a cross country trek with a defeated general, a misplaced princess, and 200 gold pieces.  No one could create the world of feudal Japan like Kurosawa and his seminal picture weaves action/adventure and comedy into a heavenly melange set against a ruthless, medieval civil war where honor and loyalty are compromised in the service of self-preservation.  That Kurosawa was able to contemplate his usual cultural themes and make The Hidden Fortress the tremendous entertainer it is, is a testament to the director's uncanny virtuosity.  George Lucas took notice and modeled much of his original Star Wars after the ground Kurosawa had tread in The Hidden Fortress -- a minor masterpiece by the legendary filmmaker, but possibly his most enjoyable.

The best part for me was watching the film that inspired the man whose films inspired me.  You can see where George Lucas got a lot of his inspiration for the Star Wars saga in this film.  There's the obvious like C-3P0, R2D2, Han Solo, and Princess Leia, but then there's Lando Calrissian, the Storm Troopers, and even the Ewoks (tell me the fire festival doesn't remind you of the Ewok scenes!).  It definitely added a layer to the experience.

If you're a fan of Akira Kurosawa, like I am, then you will love The Hidden Fortress.

Akira Kurosawa's The Hidden Fortress is a very well made and interesting film. Set in medieval Japan, the deterioration of one of the major dynasties has forced the princess into hiding out at their hidden fortress. Initially following two peasants who accidentally discover a piece of the dynasty's hidden gold, they are then followed by a great general who enlists their help in transporting the gold and the princess back to her kingdom. Reading some of the reviews for this film, I've now found out that apparently was a heavy influence for Star Wars. And that does make quite a bit of sense, especially since I was thinking about Star Wars and Jedi fights during the fight between the two generals. Anyways, the good things about the film is it looks great, as always expected with Kurosawa, and the performances are all very good, and it's actually surprisingly a bit comical to top things off. But I did think it was overlong and some of the editing is horrific, even for an old film. Overall though, a Kurosawa film is never a wrong film to check out, so check this one out.

Wednesday, March 10, 2010

(1958) The Hidden Fortress
(In Japanese with English subtitles)

ACTION/ ADVENTURE

  It is one of the best constructed films I had ever seen involving a princess, a samurai warlord and two bumpkin idiots all hiding in their fortress that became a phenominal success in Japan which inspired writer/ director George Lucas to make his own version for English audiences called Star Wars.   The leads of Toshiro Mifune who plays General Rokurota and Misa Uehara as Princess Yuki are two of the most "valiant" and "charismatic" characters ever captured for a samurai film. 
 
This was also Kurosawa's first use of widescreen in glorious black and white with the perfect music score by Masaro Sato.

Masterpiece
4/4

A bit of a slow moving film, but very interesting nonetheless. Kurosawa never seems to do the same thing twice, so I'm always fascinated by how he frames a story and when he speeds things up and slows them down. The scenes that really stick out in this film is the amazing horse chase scene that becomes a duel and the bonfire scene. I don't really get the "Star Wars" connections that much, but the two peasant characters were interesting in their own right. Misa Uehara was simply annoying for the most part, but she had her moments. More could have been done with her character that could have probably helped with the plodding pace. Still, a very good film.
